description.narrative:
Tamer institute is a protection actor that works on child protection in Gaza. In this project Tamer will be managing and analyzing information on children registered in the case management system (family centers), identify response plans for children and co-design specific services that require development. Selection of beneficiaries will be carried out based on the following assessments: A) Assessment of the current DGD project pool (livelihood capacity assessment) B) Assessment of HHs of detected children through the Tamer network and of children referred by protection actors who are qualified to receive livelihood support. The criteria for selection of CfP will be based on the end line data from the current project funded by DGD which would highlight those with remaining protection concerns, and the assessment results (of assessment A) who are found not eligible for the livelihood intervention due to protection concerns The criteria for selection of livelihood beneficiaries will be based on the lack of severe protection needs and absence of protection risks, in addition to livelihood capacities which include having relevant assets, previous experience, relevant skills and education, social network, level of indebtedness, willingness to start/ improve a livelihood activity and having an initial IGA idea, ability to invest in learning (time and effort), etc.
• The selection criteria for communities to implement the community-based protection outcome will include: o Vulnerability level of the community (especially related to access to humanitarian needs and protection services) o Number of targeted HHs from the community with protection and/or humanitarian needs without any potential for improvement on livelihood due to severe socio-economic and protection indicators MPCA will be provided to all beneficiaries as means to ensure the effectiveness of the main intervention (the livelihood and the protection intervention).

participating-org.narrative: TAMER Institute for Community Education is an educational non-governmental and non-profit organization established in 1989 to respond to the urgent needs of the Palestinian community during the first intifada. The organization focus on the rights to education, identity, freedom of expression, access to information and protection. Tamer works across the West Bank and Gaza Strip, primarily targeting children and young adults. Over the past decades, Tamer Institute has been providing a wide range of civil society engagement,remedial education and gender-sensitive programs designed to address different vulnerabilities through educational support programsbased on life skills education, stories, expressive arts, recreational activities, theatre, youth-led protection initiatives, child/parent interaction programs and awareness-raising, with a special focus on community engagement. Tamer institute relies on three pillars to implement its gender-sensitive approach: participatory planning approach, gender-aware staff and gender balancing activities. Tamer#s activities are designed to be aligned with the Child Protection Minimum Standards and MHPSS IASC Guidelines. Through its various programs, Tamer targets vulnerable children who are most in need of education, and who lack access to essential services. Italso responds to the needs of displaced children and families in the most affected areas, allowing them to build resilience and school achievements. Tamer is a member in Mental Health and Psychosocial Support group (protection cluster subgroup), CPN of MoSD and work together with different service providers and child protection organizations to ensure children access high-quality services andprevent duplication in providing the services. Tamer Institute responds to child protection concerns and runs 12 centres all over the Gaza Strip located in 6 spaces, each consisting of 5 centres: one Hub Centre; 2 Satellite Libraries; 1 School and 1 Kindergarten.Centres aim at improving the psychosocial well-being ofvulnerable children and promoting the best practices, while minimizing harmful practices in raising children for caregivers. Case manager inside centres respond to different concerns such as neglect and emotional abuse, physical violence against children,injured children, unaccompanied and separated children, child labour and injured children. Tamer started employing the case management approach and employed 10 trained case managers at the family centres[1] to providevulnerable children with child protection services. Since 2016, more than 3000 children received the case management services. Tamer has a supervisor over the case managers to provide them with required technical support of the CP SoPs and follow up the process of providing the case management service to ensure the quality of the service. Tamer uses the Child Protection Case Information Management System for documenting children cases supported through case management in its centres.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security
